clinical_study.brief_title: Acute Pain Trajectories and Persistent Pain After Breast Cancer Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Acute Pain Trajectories as a Predictive Factor for Persistent Pain After Breast Cancer Surgery

lead_sponsor.agency: Cliniques universitaires Saint-Luc- Université Catholique de Louvain

clinical_study.source: Cliniques universitaires Saint-Luc- Université Catholique de Louvain

brief_summary.textblock: Persistent pain after breast cancer surgery (PPBCS) is a significant clinical problem, affecting between 25 and 50% of patients. Several factors are associated with the development of PPBCS, including acute postoperative pain. The analysis of pain trajectories through mixed model modeling is an alternative to static pain measures, improving precision and providing information on the time course of pain resolution. Our aim was to investigate if the characteristics of pain trajectories during the first postoperative week are correlated with the persistence of pain 3 months after breast cancer surgery.

primary_outcome.measure: Presence of pain 3 months after surgery, assessed with the Brief Pain Inventory questionnaire. Yes/No

secondary_outcome.measure: Acute pain trajectories (7 days) after surgery
secondary_outcome.description: The pain trajectory is the vector of 7 verbal numerical pain scores (from 0 to 10) recorded in a pain diary over the first 7 postoperative days

arm_group.description: The study population consists of adult surgery patients, scheduled for breast cancer surgery at St-Luc University Hospital.

study_pop.textblock: Adult females, scheduled for breast cancer surgery

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Scheduled for breast cancer surgery
- General anesthesia
Exclusion Criteria:
- Previous breast surgery
- Reconstructive surgery scheduled during follow-up
- Day-surgery patients
- Inability to understand the questionnaires
